title: Part 1: Introduction
topic: History, definition, and scope of psychophysiology.

questions.question: In psychophysiological research, what is typically the dependent variable (DV)?
questions.explanation: Psychophysiology commonly treats physiology as the DV and a behavioral/psychological manipulation as the IV. Ref: Part 1 Introduction, slide 19.

questions.question: Which statement best captures the psychophysiological inference?

options.text: Physiological changes always cause psychological states
A psychological state (Ψ) is assumed to be expressed as a physiological state (Φ)
Physiological and psychological states are independent
Only hormones can reveal psychological states

questions.explanation: The inference is Ψ → Φ (psychological state expressed in physiology). Ref: Part 1 Introduction, slide 20; Part 4 Experimentation, slide 22.

questions.question: Which theory claims that emotion is the result of interpreting physiological changes?
questions.explanation: James–Lange proposes we feel emotion because we perceive bodily changes. Ref: Part 1 Introduction, slide 8.

questions.question: What did Hans Berger’s 1924 work primarily contribute to psychophysiology?

options.text: First recording of EEG from a living human

questions.explanation: Berger performed first measures on a living human brain (EEG). Ref: Part 1 Introduction, slide 12.

questions.question: Which list contains only examples of modalities within the scope of psychophysiology as presented?
questions.explanation: The scope includes cardiac/hemodynamic measures (ECG), electrodermal activity (EDA), and EEG. Ref: Part 1 Introduction, slide 22.

questions.question: Which pair is correctly matched to the 'mind–body problem' positions?

options.text: Monism: mind and body are separate; Dualism: one substance explains both
Monism: one thing explains mind and body; Dualism: separate things are needed
Monism: only the body exists; Dualism: only the mind exists

questions.explanation: Monists argue one substance explains both; dualists argue distinct substances. Ref: Part 1 Introduction, slide 4.

questions.question: Why is psychophysiology often valuable compared with purely self-report methods?

options.text: It guarantees one-to-one mapping of mind to body
It can reveal processes that would not otherwise be revealed (or would be biased in self-report)
It eliminates the need for experimental design

questions.explanation: The lecture notes emphasize psychophysiology can reveal things otherwise not revealed; mappings are not one-to-one. Ref: Part 1 Introduction, slide 29.

questions.question: Which example best illustrates early psychophysiological measurement of brain currents before EEG in humans?

options.text: Richard Caton’s galvanometer recordings from rabbit/monkey brain surface

questions.explanation: Caton observed electrical impulses from animal brain surfaces using a galvanometer. Ref: Part 1 Introduction, slide 11.

questions.question: Psychophysiological relations between psychological phenomena and physiology are generally described as:

options.text: Always mediated by the endocrine system

questions.explanation: The introduction emphasizes non-causal, non one-to-one relations. Ref: Part 1 Introduction, slide 29.

questions.question: The Society for Psychophysiological Research (SPR) was founded in:
questions.explanation: The lecture states SPR was founded in 1960. Ref: Part 1 Introduction, slide 13.

title: Part 2.1: Nervous system overview
topic: Structural vs functional divisions; somatic vs autonomic; sympathetic vs parasympathetic.

questions.question: Structurally, the central nervous system (CNS) refers to:

options.text: All nerves outside the brain and spinal cord

questions.explanation: CNS = brain and spinal cord (dorsal body cavity). Ref: Part 2.1 Nervous system, slide 1.

questions.question: Functionally, which system controls voluntary striated muscles?
questions.explanation: Somatic NS controls interaction with external environment incl. voluntary striated muscle activity. Ref: Part 2.1, slide 3.

questions.question: The autonomic nervous system primarily controls:

options.text: Internal environment: glands and organs, smooth and cardiac muscles

questions.explanation: ANS controls glands, organs, smooth and cardiac muscles (involuntary). Ref: Part 2.1, slide 3.

questions.question: Which pairing is correct?

options.text: Sympathetic: rest and digest; Parasympathetic: fight or flight
Sympathetic: fight or flight; Parasympathetic: rest and digest
Both are dominant during acute stress

questions.explanation: Sympathetic dominates fight/flight; parasympathetic dominates rest/digest. Ref: Part 2.1, slide 4.

questions.question: The nervous system is defined structurally as:
questions.explanation: Lecture defines NS as collection of neurons and supportive glial cells. Ref: Part 2.1, slide 1.

questions.question: Which statement about endocrine communication is consistent with the lecture?

options.text: The endocrine system is independent of the nervous system
The endocrine system uses hormones and is largely controlled by the nervous system
The nervous system uses hormones for communication
Endocrine signaling is faster than neural signaling

questions.explanation: The endocrine system uses hormones, but is largely controlled by the nervous system. Ref: Part 2.1, slide 2.

questions.question: Which is the correct structural division of the nervous system?
questions.explanation: Structural division: CNS vs PNS. Ref: Part 2.1, slide 1 and 6.

questions.question: Which is an example of a measure that can reflect autonomic nervous system activity in psychophysiology (as shown in the overview slide)?
questions.explanation: Overview slide lists skin conductance, heart rate etc. as psychophysiological measures. Ref: Part 2.1, slide 6.

questions.question: The peripheral nervous system (PNS) refers to:

options.text: Parts of neurons outside brain and spinal cord

questions.explanation: PNS includes neuronal parts outside brain/spinal cord. Ref: Part 2.1, slide 1.

questions.question: The sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems are best described as:

options.text: Antagonistic subsystems of the autonomic nervous system
Subsystems of the somatic nervous system

questions.explanation: They are antagonistic ANS subsystems (fight/flight vs rest/digest). Ref: Part 2.1, slide 7.

title: Part 2.2: Neurons and neuronal signalling
topic: Neuron structure, resting potential, synapses, summation, action potentials.

questions.question: The resting potential of neurons is approximately:
questions.explanation: Resting potential ~ -70 mV. Ref: Part 2.2 Neurons, slide 8.

questions.question: Which mechanism actively maintains the resting potential by transporting ions?
questions.explanation: Na⁺/K⁺ pump transports Na⁺ out and K⁺ in. Ref: Part 2.2, slide 8.

questions.question: A motor unit consists of:

options.text: One muscle fiber and one sensory neuron
A motor neuron, its axon, and all muscle fibers it innervates

questions.explanation: Definition given in EMG lecture, but concept aligns with neuronal signaling; motor unit defined as single motor neuron + fibers. Ref: Part 5 EMG, slide 15.

questions.question: Which type of neuron is also called an afferent neuron?
questions.explanation: Sensory neurons are afferent. Ref: Part 2.2, slide 3.

questions.question: Temporal summation refers to:

options.text: Summing inputs from different synapses at the same time
Summing repeated inputs from the same synapse over time
Conduction jumping between nodes of Ranvier

questions.explanation: Temporal summation = repeated PSPs over time at a synapse. Ref: Part 2.2, slide 15.

questions.question: Spatial summation refers to:

options.text: Summing inputs from multiple synapses at different locations
Summing repeated inputs from one synapse

questions.explanation: Spatial summation = PSPs from multiple synapses combine at axon hillock. Ref: Part 2.2, slide 16.

questions.question: Voltage-gated ion channels that generate action potentials open when:

options.text: Membrane potential becomes more negative than resting
Membrane potential reaches a threshold above resting

questions.explanation: They open when membrane potential increases to threshold. Ref: Part 2.2, slides 21–22.

questions.question: Saltatory conduction occurs in:

options.text: Myelinated axons, where the action potential 'jumps' between nodes of Ranvier

questions.explanation: Saltatory conduction uses myelin sheath and nodes of Ranvier. Ref: Part 2.2, slide 27.

questions.question: The axon hillock is primarily important because it is:

options.text: The main integration zone where action potentials are initiated if threshold is reached
The location of the Na⁺/K⁺ pump only

questions.explanation: PSPs sum at axon hillock; AP initiated if above threshold. Ref: Part 2.2, slides 14 and 20.

questions.question: Excitatory and inhibitory postsynaptic potentials are abbreviated as:
questions.explanation: EPSP (excitatory) and IPSP (inhibitory). Ref: Part 2.2, slide 17.

title: Part 2.3: Central nervous system
topic: Anatomical terminology, spinal cord, brain divisions, key structures.

questions.question: In the CNS, a bundle of axons is called a:
questions.explanation: In PNS it's a nerve; in CNS it's a tract. Ref: Part 2.3 CNS, slide 5.

questions.question: In the CNS, a group of neuron cell bodies is called a:
questions.explanation: Ganglion (PNS) corresponds to nucleus (CNS). Ref: Part 2.3, slide 5.

questions.question: Afferent nerves conduct signals:
questions.explanation: Afferent = toward CNS. Ref: Part 2.3, slide 5.

questions.question: Posterior (dorsal) roots of spinal nerves are primarily:
questions.explanation: Posterior root is afferent sensory; anterior is efferent motor. Ref: Part 2.3, slide 9.

questions.question: The spinal cord is responsible for transporting signals and also for:
questions.explanation: Spinal cord transports afferent/efferent signals and processes reflexes. Ref: Part 2.3, slide 13.

questions.question: Which hindbrain structure controls autonomic functions like breathing and heartbeat?
questions.explanation: Medulla controls autonomic functions. Ref: Part 2.3, slide 18.

questions.question: The limbic system is primarily associated with:
questions.explanation: Limbic system: emotion (amygdala) and memory (hippocampus). Ref: Part 2.3, slide 21.

questions.question: Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is described as:

options.text: Produced only in the spinal cord; does not circulate
Produced in ventricles; circulates and provides mechanical protection and transport
Produced in the liver; transported in blood

questions.explanation: CSF produced in ventricles, circulates, provides protection and transport. Ref: Part 2.3, slide 27.

questions.question: Brodmann areas refer to:

options.text: 52 cortical areas classified by cellular properties

questions.explanation: Brodmann identified 52 areas based on cellular size/density/layering. Ref: Part 2.3, slide 30.

questions.question: The motor cortex and primary somatosensory cortex are organized:
questions.explanation: Somatotopic maps; organization is contralateral. Ref: Part 2.3, slide 32.

title: Part 3: Psychophysiological measurement
topic: Electricity, electrodes, digitization, sampling, and filtering.

questions.question: Biosignals are best defined as:

options.text: Directly measurable, time-varying parameters reflecting physiological activity

questions.explanation: Lecture definition: directly measurable, time-varying physiological parameters. Ref: Part 3 Measurement, slide 2.

questions.question: According to Ohm’s law, resistance (R) equals:
questions.explanation: Ohm’s law: R = V / I. Ref: Part 3, slide 6.

questions.question: Impedance is best described as:
questions.explanation: Impedance is resistance for alternating currents. Ref: Part 3, slide 5.

questions.question: To record one channel of biopotentials, what electrode roles are typically required?

options.text: Recording electrode, reference electrode, and ground electrode

questions.explanation: Most recordings use recording, reference, and ground electrodes. Ref: Part 3, slide 13.

questions.question: In a bipolar measurement, each recorded channel reflects:

options.text: Voltage of one electrode relative to a shared reference

questions.explanation: Bipolar = difference between two electrodes. Ref: Part 3, slide 14.

questions.question: Why is there no truly 'electrically neutral' reference location on the body?

options.text: Because the body is always at 0 V
Because electric fields spread and all sites pick up activity

questions.explanation: Lecture notes: no electrically neutral reference on the human body. Ref: Part 3, slide 16.

questions.question: The Nyquist frequency is:

options.text: The same as the filter cutoff

questions.explanation: Nyquist frequency = half the sampling rate. Ref: Part 3, slide 26.

questions.question: Aliasing occurs when:

options.text: Frequencies above the Nyquist frequency are present and get distorted

questions.explanation: Frequencies higher than Nyquist are affected by aliasing. Ref: Part 3, slide 26.

questions.question: A notch filter is designed to:

options.text: Attenuate all frequencies above a threshold
Attenuate all frequencies below a threshold

questions.explanation: Notch filters attenuate a single frequency (e.g., 50 Hz line noise). Ref: Part 3, slide 33.

questions.question: Why is choosing the sampling rate during recording especially important?

options.text: It can always be corrected later without loss
Sampling rate and some filters configured during recording cannot be undone
Sampling rate only affects file size

questions.explanation: Sampling rate and some filters are set during recording; cannot be undone. Ref: Part 3, slide 34.

title: Part 4: Psychophysiological experimentation
topic: Scientific method, variables, within/between designs, event-related analysis, artefacts.

questions.question: Operationalisation is best described as:

options.text: Defining a concept/construct in terms of measurable criteria

questions.explanation: Operationalisation creates definitions in measurable/testable terms. Ref: Part 4 Experimentation, slide 5.

questions.question: In an experiment, the independent variable (IV) is typically:
questions.explanation: IV is manipulated to induce effect; DV measured to reveal it. Ref: Part 4, slide 8.

questions.question: A mediating variable (MeV) is:

options.text: Manipulated directly to cause DV changes
Used to explain the mechanism of the IV–DV relationship

questions.explanation: MeV explains mechanism but is not manipulated directly. Ref: Part 4, slide 12.

questions.question: A confounding variable (CfV) is best described as:

options.text: Any variable that can be ignored safely
An extraneous variable we cannot (or forgot to) control for, risking bias
A variable that is always part of the theoretical model
A variable that improves measurement precision

questions.explanation: CfV is a relevant EV not controlled for, causing bias/spurious relations. Ref: Part 4, slides 17–18.

questions.question: Why are within-subjects designs common in psychophysiology?

options.text: Between-subject variability is large; within-subject variability tends to be lower
They eliminate the need for randomization

questions.explanation: Large individual differences; within-subject variability lower. Ref: Part 4, slide 25.

questions.question: Balanced or randomized condition orders in within-subject designs primarily help control for:
questions.explanation: Balancing/randomizing helps control temporal effects like fatigue. Ref: Part 4, slides 26–27.

questions.question: Serial dependency refers to:

options.text: Order effects where prior conditions influence perception/behavior in later conditions

questions.explanation: Serial dependency: behavior depends on which condition came first. Ref: Part 4, slide 28.

questions.question: Event-related analysis focuses on:

options.text: A whole condition summarized as one DV parameter
Changes in physiology relative to specific events in small time windows

questions.explanation: Event-related = time windows relative to events. Ref: Part 4, slide 32.

questions.question: Epoching in EEG analysis means:

options.text: Filtering out all frequencies above 50 Hz
Extracting time segments relative to events from a continuous recording

questions.explanation: Epoching extracts time segments around events. Ref: Part 4, slide 34.

questions.question: Which is an example of an external artefact described in the lecture?
questions.explanation: External artefacts include electromagnetic 50 Hz line noise. Ref: Part 4, slide 40.

title: Part 5: Electromyography
topic: Origins, recording, artefacts, and analysis of EMG including rectification/integration.

questions.question: Electromyography (EMG) primarily measures:

options.text: Electrical activity from muscle fiber action potentials (summed as motor unit potentials)

questions.explanation: EMG measures summed muscle fiber APs of motor units (MUPs). Ref: Part 5 EMG, slide 18.

questions.question: Which muscle type is voluntary and controlled by the somatic nervous system?
questions.explanation: Skeletal muscle is striated and voluntary, SNS-controlled. Ref: Part 5, slide 7.

questions.question: A motor unit follows which activation principle?
questions.explanation: Activation of a motor unit follows all-or-nothing. Ref: Part 5, slide 15.

questions.question: Why is the raw EMG often described as broadband?

options.text: Only one motor unit fires at exactly 10 Hz
Multiple motor units fire up to ~50 Hz each, but combined activity yields higher frequencies
Because EMG is always filtered to 0–4 Hz

questions.explanation: Many motor units firing contribute to higher-frequency broadband signal. Ref: Part 5, slide 18.

questions.question: For typical surface EMG, the amplifier should capture most power in approximately which range?
questions.explanation: Lecture notes most power in 40–100 Hz. Ref: Part 5, slide 22.

questions.question: A common EMG preprocessing pipeline includes rectification followed by:
questions.explanation: Processing: rectification, smoothing, integration. Ref: Part 5, slide 31.

questions.question: Full-wave rectification means:
questions.explanation: Full-wave rectification = absolute values. Ref: Part 5, slide 31.

questions.question: Why are absolute EMG values often considered meaningless across sessions or placements?

options.text: EMG cannot be measured with electrodes
Small placement differences (mm) can change the signal substantially
EMG is always identical across people

questions.explanation: A few mm in placement can change EMG; repeated measures difficult. Ref: Part 5, slide 23.

questions.question: Which facial muscle is associated with frowning (as listed)?
questions.explanation: Corrugator = frown. Ref: Part 5, slide 25.

questions.question: Integration of EMG output reflects:

options.text: Total EMG output over a chosen time period

questions.explanation: Integration reflects total EMG output over a period (free parameter). Ref: Part 5, slide 32.

title: Part 6.1: Cardiovascular system
topic: Heart and vessels, conduction system, pacemaker cells, autonomic modulation.

questions.question: The main function of the cardiovascular system is to:

options.text: Transport blood to and from organs to deliver oxygen/nutrients and remove waste

questions.explanation: Transport blood; deliver oxygen/nutrients, remove waste; regulate temperature etc. Ref: Part 6.1 Cardiovascular system, slide 2.

questions.question: Arteries generally carry blood:
questions.explanation: Arteries carry blood away from heart. Ref: Part 6.1, slide 4.

questions.question: Veins generally carry blood:
questions.explanation: Veins carry blood toward heart. Ref: Part 6.1, slide 4.

questions.question: Capillaries are important because:

options.text: They allow exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste through their walls

questions.explanation: Capillaries are microvessels enabling exchange. Ref: Part 6.1, slide 4.

questions.question: Pacemaker cells are characterized by:

options.text: Stable resting potential that never depolarizes
Being controlled only by voluntary motor neurons

questions.explanation: Pacemaker cells depolarize spontaneously, causing autorhythmicity. Ref: Part 6.1, slide 12.

questions.question: Cardiac muscle cells are connected via gap junctions mainly to:

options.text: Allow cardiac action potentials to conduct between cells

questions.explanation: Gap junctions allow free conduction between cardiomyocytes. Ref: Part 6.1, slide 12.

questions.question: The sinoatrial (SA) node is located:

options.text: At the superior wall of the right atrium

questions.explanation: SA node location: superior wall of right atrium. Ref: Part 6.1, slide 15.

questions.question: In the cardiac conduction pathway, which structure delays the signal to allow atrial contraction?
questions.explanation: AV node delays the signal. Ref: Part 6.1, slide 15.

questions.question: The SA node’s intrinsic rhythmicity is about:
questions.explanation: SA node intrinsic rhythm ~100 bpm. Ref: Part 6.1, slide 17.

questions.question: A denervated heart would beat at around:
questions.explanation: Without ANS modulation, heart beats ~100 bpm. Ref: Part 6.1, slide 17.

title: Part 6.2: Cardiovascular measures
topic: Blood pressure, PPG, ECG, heart rate and HRV metrics.

questions.question: In medicine, blood pressure is commonly expressed in:
questions.explanation: Blood pressure commonly in mmHg rather than Pascal. Ref: Part 6.2 Cardiovascular measures, slide 3.

questions.question: Blood pressure in the systemic circulation varies between:
questions.explanation: BP varies between systolic and diastolic. Ref: Part 6.2, slide 10.

questions.question: The baroreflex response to increased blood pressure is:
questions.explanation: Increased BP sensed → decreased cardiac output (and vice versa). Ref: Part 6.2, slide 5.

questions.question: Most blood vessels have which autonomic innervation (as described)?
questions.explanation: Most vessels only sympathetic; mostly vasoconstriction. Ref: Part 6.2, slide 6.

questions.question: A key disadvantage of sphygmomanometry is that it is:

options.text: Not continuously measurable and temporarily deforms arteries

questions.explanation: Disadvantages: not continuous; deforms arteries; allow recovery. Ref: Part 6.2, slide 8.

questions.question: Continuous measurement of true blood pressure is only possible:
questions.explanation: True continuous BP only invasive (arterial line). Ref: Part 6.2, slide 9.

questions.question: Peripheral blood volume is often measured at the finger because:

options.text: It contains the largest skeletal muscles
Many vessels are close to the skin and it’s not complicated by skeletal muscles
It is controlled by the parasympathetic system

questions.explanation: Finger has many vessels near surface; minimal skeletal muscle interference. Ref: Part 6.2, slide 13.

questions.question: Vasomotor activity in the skin is described as being under:
questions.explanation: Skin vasomotor activity exclusively sympathetic. Ref: Part 6.2, slide 13.

questions.question: Photoplethysmography (PPG) uses ______ to detect changes in blood volume indirectly.
questions.explanation: PPG uses infrared light; detects absorption/refraction changes. Ref: Part 6.2, slide 14.

questions.question: In an ECG, the R peaks are commonly used to compute:
questions.explanation: HR is operationalized as number of R peaks per minute. Ref: Part 6.2, slide 29.

title: Part 7: Electrodermal activity
topic: Skin anatomy, eccrine glands, recording conductance, tonic/phasic analysis.

questions.question: Electrodermal activity (EDA) is most directly linked to activity of:
questions.explanation: Eccrine sweat glands are the main factor in skin conductance. Ref: Part 7 EDA, slide 21.

questions.question: Eccrine sweat glands are under ______ control (as stated).
questions.explanation: Eccrine glands are exclusively sympathetic. Ref: Part 7, slide 22.

questions.question: For skin conductance recordings, which recording configuration is preferred?
questions.explanation: Bipolar preferred for conductance; unipolar for potential. Ref: Part 7, slide 27.

questions.question: A common recording site for peripheral skin conductance is:
questions.explanation: Non-dominant hand often used; palms/fingers high eccrine density. Ref: Part 7, slide 28 and 21.

questions.question: In the lecture’s EDA analysis, tonic changes correspond to:
questions.explanation: Tonic = SCL; phasic = SCR. Ref: Part 7, slide 31.

questions.question: Phasic EDA changes are typically called:
questions.explanation: Phasic = SCR. Ref: Part 7, slide 31.

questions.question: Why is interpreting absolute SCL as 'general arousal level' considered wrong?
questions.explanation: Tonic SCL varies greatly between individuals; absolute interpretation is wrong. Ref: Part 7, slide 33.

questions.question: A non-specific fluctuation in EDA is defined as occurring, for example:

options.text: More than 5 seconds after any known stimulus

questions.explanation: Non-specific fluctuation defined e.g. >5 s after known stimulus. Ref: Part 7, slide 33.

questions.question: Which factor is listed as a common EDA artefact source?
questions.explanation: Artefacts: temperature, humidity, respiratory/cardiac cycle, etc. Ref: Part 7, slide 29.

questions.question: The traditional non-SI unit equivalent to siemens mentioned for conductance is:
questions.explanation: mho is a traditional unit equivalent to siemens. Ref: Part 7, slide 26.

title: Part 8.1: Electrocortical activity
topic: Physiological origins of EEG; volume conduction; comparison with MEG/fMRI/fNIRS/ECoG.

questions.question: EEG recorded at the scalp primarily reflects synchronous activity of:

options.text: Postsynaptic potentials in large neuronal populations

questions.explanation: Action potentials too fast; PSPs last longer and can summate. Ref: Part 8.1 Electrocortical activity, slide 18.

questions.question: Why are action potentials usually not the main contributor to scalp EEG?

options.text: They are too fast (1–2 ms) to be synchronous over large populations

questions.explanation: APs are too fast to synchronise across large populations. Ref: Part 8.1, slide 18.

questions.question: For scalp EEG to be measurable, synchronous activity must also have an appropriate spatial organization. This is typically true for:
questions.explanation: Pyramidal cells have arrangement that avoids cancellation. Ref: Part 8.1, slides 18–21.

questions.question: EEG has relatively low spatial resolution mainly because:

options.text: Each electrode records activity from millions of neurons and signals spread via volume conduction

questions.explanation: One electrode reflects 10–1000 million neurons; volume conduction contributes. Ref: Part 8.1, slides 22–23.

questions.question: Volume conduction implies that electric fields in EEG:

options.text: Spread instantaneously and reach the scalp broadly
Require the skull to be magnetically transparent
Depend only on the reference electrode being neutral

questions.explanation: Spread is instantaneous and broad; no neutral reference. Ref: Part 8.1, slide 23.

questions.question: Which is listed as an advantage of EEG compared to fMRI?

options.text: Ability to measure deep brain structures

questions.explanation: EEG: high temporal resolution. Ref: Part 8.1, slide 28.

questions.question: MEG is described as being reference-free primarily because it measures:

options.text: Magnetic fields produced by brain currents

questions.explanation: MEG measures magnetic fields from electrical currents. Ref: Part 8.1, slides 29–30.

questions.question: fMRI detects brain activity indirectly by measuring:
questions.explanation: fMRI: changes in blood oxygenation near active tissue. Ref: Part 8.1, slide 31.

questions.question: ECoG differs from EEG because ECoG electrodes are placed:
questions.explanation: ECoG uses electrodes on cortical surface (invasive). Ref: Part 8.1, slide 35.

questions.question: The lecture states that physiological origins of EEG can be summarized as:

options.text: Synchronous action potentials at axon terminals
Synchronous postsynaptic potentials at apical dendrites of pyramidal cells on the cortical surface

questions.explanation: EEG originates from synchronous PSPs at apical dendrites of pyramidal cells in cortex. Ref: Part 8.1, slide 25.

title: Part 8.2: Electrocortical measures
topic: EEG recording (10–20), rhythms, spectral and ERP analyses, time-frequency methods.

questions.question: The international 10–20 system uses fiducials including:
questions.explanation: 10–20 system fiducials: nasion, pre-auricular points, inion. Ref: Part 8.2, slide 7.

questions.question: In the 10–20 naming convention, odd numbers typically indicate electrodes on the:
questions.explanation: Odd = left, even = right, z = midline. Ref: Part 8.2, slide 9.

questions.question: Why is skin preparation and gel used when applying EEG electrodes?

options.text: To reduce impedance and stabilize the connection against movement
To eliminate the need for a reference electrode

questions.explanation: Cleaning/abrading + gel reduces impedance and increases stability. Ref: Part 8.2, slide 11.

questions.question: To avoid aliasing when interested in EEG frequencies up to 100 Hz, the lecture suggests sampling at around:
questions.explanation: Record 5–10× highest frequency; e.g., 1000 Hz with low-pass at 500 Hz. Ref: Part 8.2, slide 12.

questions.question: A prominent artefact source in EEG recordings is:

options.text: Eye movements and blinks via the corneo-retinal dipole

questions.explanation: Eye movements/blinks are prominent due to corneo-retinal dipole. Ref: Part 8.2, slides 14–15.

questions.question: Alpha rhythm is typically defined as:
questions.explanation: Alpha is 8–12 Hz. Ref: Part 8.2, slide 22.

questions.question: Alpha desynchronization (reduced alpha) is associated with:
questions.explanation: Reduced alpha associated with attention/cognitive work; often with increased theta. Ref: Part 8.2, slide 22.

questions.question: The event-related potential (ERP) is:

options.text: A power spectrum of ongoing EEG
A segment of EEG investigated relative to a specific event
A measure of peripheral blood volume

questions.explanation: ERP = EEG segment time-locked to event. Ref: Part 8.2, slide 43.

questions.question: Why are multiple epochs averaged in ERP analysis?

options.text: Single-trial ERPs are too noisy; averaging cancels non-systematic activity
Because EEG is discrete rather than continuous

questions.explanation: Averaging across epochs cancels activity not systematically related to event/baseline. Ref: Part 8.2, slides 44–45.

questions.question: A difference wave is created by:

options.text: Subtracting one condition’s ERP from another at each time sample

questions.explanation: Difference wave subtracts ERP amplitudes sample-by-sample. Ref: Part 8.2, slide 49.
